title: Alondra Esperanza Nina Meneces
description: Alondra Esperanza Nina Meneces is a clarinet performer, clinician, and teacher-based in the Dallas-Forth Worth (DFW) Metroplex in Texas. She won the first version of the Bolivian Clarinetists and Saxophonists National Competition in 2006 in Bolivia, her birth country. In 2014, she migrated to the United States to pursue an Undergraduate Degree at Sam Houston State University and a Graduate Degree at the University of North Texas under Dr. Patricia Card and Dr. Phillip Paglialonga, respectively. She has performed in Bolivia, Argentina, Houston, Dallas, and Denver festivals. Alondra performs with the Mansfield Philharmonic Orchestra, Mansfield Winds, and North Central Texas Winds at the North Central Texas College (NCTC) and substitutes for the Mesquite Philharmonic Orchestra in Mesquite, Texas, and the San Angelo Symphony in San Angelo, Texas. She is also a private instructor at Richardson Independent School District (ISD) and Garland ISD in DFW.
keywords: clarinetist; performer; clinician; educator; Bolivian Clarinetists and Saxophonists National Competition; Sam Houston State University; Texas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Andres Bravo
description:
Bravo established his performance and teaching career in Dallas, Texas. As a performer, he has performed as a soloist with Bolivian orchestras and in the US. Bravo has also played alongside members of the Escher Quartet, Viano Quartet, Julius Quartet, and soloists Nicola Benedetti, Aaron Boyd, Philip Quint, Jaime Laredo, and Paul Neubauer. He has been appointed concertmaster and principal second in orchestras at Interlochen Center for the Arts in Interlochen in Curtis, Michigan; Eastern Music Festival in Greensboro, North Carolina; Immanuel & Helen Olshan Texas Music Festival at the University of Houston; Round Top Music Festival at the Round Top Festival Institute in Round Top, Texas; Bolivia Clasica; the Sam Houston State University Symphony Orchestra; and the Southern Methodist University Meadows Symphony Orchestra. He has also been a guest artist at the Erikson Center of the Arts in Curtis, Michigan, for the past few years. Currently, Bravo holds positions with the East Texas Symphony Orchestra, Abilene Philharmonic Orchestra in Abilene, Texas, and McKinney Philharmonic Orchestra in Forth Worth, Texas. He also regularly plays with the Plano Symphony Orchestra in North Texas and the Irving Symphony Orchestra in Irving, Texas.
Born in La Paz, Bolivia, Bravo started learning the violin at nine years old with his mother, Elizabeth Canedo de Bravo. Shortly after, he entered the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] in La Paz at 11 and studied violin with Maestro Ramiro Jimenez. At fourteen, he joined the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia and played there until 2012. Bravo received his bachelor's in Music Performance from Sam Houston State University, where he studied with Javier Pinell and Nahomi Gjevre. He also received a Performance Diploma and master’s of music in violin performance from Southern Methodist University, where he studied with Emanuel Borok, Aaron Boyd, and Alexander Sitkovetsky. As a teacher, he has been a private violin and viola teacher. Bravo has also conducted region and all-state clinics in several schools in Houston and Dallas, including Ranch View High School, D.F Long Middle School, Hebron High School, Barbara Bush Middle School, Doerre Middle School, and Rockwall School of Music. He has also worked as an assistant for the Huntsville Youth Orchestra and Bolivia Classica Youth Orchestra.
keywords: violinist; performer; educator; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Sam Houston State University; Interlochen Center for the Arts; Bolivia Clasica; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Texas; USA
creator: unknown

title: Atiliano Auza León
description:
Born in the historic city of Sucre, Bolivia, composer, violinist, and musicologist Auza Leon began his musical studies at the Academia de Música Eduardo Berdecio [the Eduardo Berdecio Academy of Music] in Sucre at the age of 18 in 1946. He transferred a year later (1947) to the Escuela Superior De Formación De Maestros de Sucre [Higher Teacher Training School of Sucre] (ESFM) (1947-1951). In 1953, Auza Leon studied composition at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz with exiled Jewish German maestro Erich Eisner, the founder and first director of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia. In 1965, he studied at the Latin American Center for Higher Musical Studies (CLAEM), a program developed in partnership with the Torcuato Di Tella Institute and the Rockefeller Foundation in Buenos Aires, Argentina, under the direction of the Argentine composer Alberto Ginastera. Upon his return to Bolivia in the 1970s, Auza Leon taught at various institutions, including the Escuela Superior De Formación De Maestros Simón Bolívar [Simón Bolívar Higher Teacher Training School of Music] in La Paz, where he directed the choir, and at the COPLUMU, where he taught composition.
Throughout his lifetime, Auza Leon has written numerous compositions for violin, choir, and orchestra, including Ramillete Sonoro (1958) in three volumes, a collection of Bolivian songs for children; Sies danzas Bolivianas del Ciclo Runas [Six Bolivian dances of the Runas cycle] (1960) which features popular songs El pañuelo [The handkerchief]  and A la cueca; the piano sonatas Anfiblástula (1965) and Los Chunchos (1979); and La Cantata Oda a Moto Méndez (1984) an ode to Bolivian freedom fighter Eustaquio "Moto" Méndez. Most notably, he wrote the music for the first Bolivian Opera, Incallajta (1980), which narrates the impossible love story between an Incan princess and a warrior. His latest compositions, Melodías Nacionales para Piano [National Melodies for Piano] (1999); Danzas Bolivianas para Violín y Piano (Ciclo Runas 2°) [Bolivian Dances for Violin and Piano (Runas 2° Cycle)] (2000); and Sinfonía Boliviana [Bolivian Symphony] (2006) in four movements demonstrate his dedication to Bolivian music. In addition to his musical work, Auza Leon has written several Bolivian music history books and published articles in the National Press. His most important works include Dinámica Musical en Bolivia [Musical Dynamics in Bolivia] (1967), Musica Contemporanea [Contemporary Music](1976), and Historia de la Música Boliviana (History of Bolivian Music) (1985), which sold-out three editions.
keywords: violinist; composer; musicologist; author; educator; Erich Eisner; Escuela Superior De Formación De Maestros De Sucre; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia
creator: unknown
source: Diccionario Cultural Boliviano by D.R. Elías Blanco

title: Canela Palacios
description: Palacios studied under composers Alberto Villalpando, Cergio Prudencio, Coriún Aharonián, Graciela Paraskevaídis, and Cornelius Schwehr. In 2011, she founded, together with several colleagues, the Casa Taller collective, a meeting and creation space in La Paz. In 2015, with the Casa Taller team, Palacios created the “School of Composition,” of which she was director. She is the creator and person in charge of the Bolivian Contemporary Music Project. She was the co-founder, composer, and performer of songs of the Abrelata Duo. Palacios has composed for contemporary music ensembles from Bolivia and other countries. Her music has been performed at contemporary festivals in Bolivia, Colombia, and Germany. She has also collaborated with artists from various disciplines in dance, theater, film, and performance projects. In 2020, she published the popular music album Sur [South].
keywords: guitarist; composer; contemporary music; popular music; Alberto Villalpando; Cergio Prudencio Bolivian Contemporary Music Project
creator: unknown
source: Inmerso- Música Contemporánea en Colombia y América Latina-Facebook

title: Cesar Blas
description: Cesar Blas started to play oboe at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] in La Paz, Bolivia 2015. He has actively played in orchestras in La Paz and Oruro. Blas earned a master’s in music performance at the University of Central Arkansas (UCA), studying with Dr. Lorraine Duso. Held the position of graduate assistant at UCA, teaching the double reed methods class to undergraduate students, and worked as an oboe instructor at Cabot High School in Cabot, Arkansas. Blas has played principal oboe at the UCA Wind Ensemble and the Conway Symphony Orchestra in Conway, Arkansas. As a chamber musician, he is a member of the UCA Woodwind Quintet and has participated in many different ensembles. Blas is currently finishing a graduate certificate program.
keywords: oboist; performer; educator; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; University of Central Arkansas; Conway Symphony Orchestra; Arkansas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Christian Orlando Asturizaga
description:
Asturizaga is the principal conductor of the Chuquiago Marka Symphony Orchestra and concertmaster of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia, where he served as director from 2015 to 2017. Asturizaga studied at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in Bolivia, Morges Conservatory in Switzerland, and the Metz Regional Conservatory in France with violinist Denis Clavier. In the United States, he received a scholarship to attend one of the Interlochen Center for the Arts Camps in Interlochen, Michigan, which changed his interest in music and led him to enhance his artistic profile. He studied conducting, composition, and arrangements at Universidad Loyola de Bolivia [Loyola University of Bolivia] in La Paz and received a master's degree in orchestral conducting from the Universidad Pública de El Alto [Public University of El Alto] and at the Escuela de Dirección de Orquesta y Banda, Maestro Francisco Navarra Lara [Maestro Francisco Navarro Lara Orchestra and Band Conducting School]. In 2007, he received recognition for his pedagogical work and contribution to Bolivian musical culture. 
Asturizaga’s artistic experience led him to perform on the main national stages, and he began his international career at an early age representing Bolivia. He participated in several orchestral projects for international conferences, such as the Interlochen World Youth Symphony Orchestra. Asturizaga has also participated in national projects such as the Orquesta Juvenil de los Países Andinos [Youth Orchestra of the Andean Countries] and the Orchestra of the Union of South American Nations (UNASUR), which allowed him to participate in concerts in Switzerland, the United States (U.S.), China, France, tours of South America, Europe, and Bolivia. As a teacher, researcher, and graduate project advisor, Asturizaga has contributed to the training of new generations at the COPLUMU in La Paz, the Instituto de Formación Artística Luis Felipe Arce [Luis Felipe Arce Artistic Training Institute], the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés [Major University of San Andres], and the Universidad Privada Boliviana [Bolivian Private University] (UPB). He has also been invited to give talks in Peru, the U.S., and France. For his contribution to Bolivian culture, he has been distinguished with the "Honor of Cultural Merit" Medal, recognition and tribute as a "Meritorious Personality of the Plurinational State of Bolivia,” the "Chukuta de Oro" and others from the Legislative Assembly. In 2022, the Club of La Paz recognized him for his remarkable career among ten other representative national artists.
keywords: violinist; composer; conductor; educator; researcher; Honor of Cultural Merit Medal; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Interlochen Center for the Arts; Universidad Loyola de Bolivia; Universidad Pública de El Alto; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia
creator: unknown

title: Eduardo Cassapia
description:
From La Paz, Bolivia, Cassapia began his studies of traditional Andean music at the Conservatorio Los Andes [Los Andes Conservatory] under the direction of Maestro Gerardo Yanez Sarmiento and studied the classical oboe at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz. He became an international artist after studying oboe and music composition with notable instructors in Berlin, Ulm, and Freiburg, Germany. Under the tutelage of the internationally recognized contemporary composer Arvo Pärt, Cassapia became distinguished as a composer in the realm of classical music as well as an arranger of traditional, native, and folk music styles. 
The National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia welcomed Cassapia home from Europe as an oboist and arts activist, receiving the “Honor of Cultural Merit” awarded by the Legislative Assembly of the Plurinational State of Bolivia. As director of the Cultural Center of Los Andes, he imparted ancestral knowledge of communitarian Andean music to underprivileged youth as a form of therapy and cultural and social development. 
Currently residing in Austin, Texas, Cassapia enjoys being on the vanguard of new musical projects and sharing his knowledge of ethnomusicology. As a soloist in the classical music scene, he took center stage, performing his arrangements and compositions for symphonic orchestra and native instruments with the Steamboat Symphony Orchestra in Steamboat Springs, Colorado and also with his project entitled “Nomads,” winning a grant from the City of Austin. He is a part of the duo NorteSur with harpist, Rachel Browne.
keywords: oboist; performer; composer; musical arranger; educator; ethnomusicologist; Honor of Cultural Merit; Rachel Browne; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; NorteSur; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Germany; Texas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Fernando Arduz
description:
Born in Tarija, Bolivia, Arduz began studying music with his hometown legend, maestro Ernesto La Faye “Don Ernesto” in 1973. He attended four international guitar seminars with Uruguayan maestro Abel Carlevaro in Montevideo, Uruguay. Arduz obtained the title of Superior Professor of Guitar at the Madrid Royal Superior Conservatory in Spain. He has directed the Tarija Chamber Orchestra since its creation and taught at La Escuela Municipal de Música Regional y Arte Pastor Achá Martínez [The Municipal School of Regional Music Pastor Achá Martínez]. He has held concerts in Bolivia, Spain, and Argentina. His compositions and arrangements have been premiered and performed in Spain by the Alfar Duo and Gabriel Estarellas; in Germany by the Trío Arabesque; in Japan by Gentaro Takada; in Argentina by Camerata Lyrum; in Bolivia by the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia, the Tajira Chamber Orchestra, and the Orquesta Sinfónica Departamental de Tarija [Departmental Symphony Orchestra of Tarija]; and by various Bolivian and foreign guitarists. 
Arduz’s body of work includes musical compositions and books. The books he published throughout his lifetime include the Música Boliviana para Guitarra [Bolivian Music for Guitar] (1993); Alfredo Domínguez, Obras para Guitarra [Alfredo Domínguez, Works for Guitar] (2002), and Pequeñas Obras y Estudios para Guitarra [Small Works and Studies for Guitar] (2004). He co-edited El Libro Música y Cantos Tradicionales de Tarija [The book of music and Traditional Songs of Tarija] (1999) with Dr. Lorenzo Calzavarini. Arduz has also collaborated with his daughter, Adriana Arduz Mendieta, to make the interactive album Enciclopedia de Música Chapaca [Encyclopedia of Chapaca Music] (2008) and with the Tarija Chamber Orchestra to record the album Tarija y la Música de él [Tarija and his music] (2009). In 2013, he released the album Paisajes: Fernando Arduz [Landscapes: Fernando Arduz]. Arduz also received recognition for his work, including the “Premio Plurinacional Eduardo Abaroa” [Eduardo Abaroa Plurination Award] from the Ministry of Culture and Tourism of the Plurinational State of Bolivia in the category of Folk music arrangement for symphony orchestra for his work Vida, pasión y muerte de Juan Cutipa de Alfredo Domínguez [Life, passion, and death of Juan Cutipa by Alfredo Domínguez] in 2014. The Ministry of Education awarded him the “ Maestro of Arts in Music” title in 2015. He passed away in Tarija in December 2021.
keywords: guitarist; composer; author; educator; Madrid Royal Superior Conservatory; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Orquesta Sinfónica Departamental de Tarija; Spain
creator: El Pais (Bolivia)

title: Gastón Arce Sejas
description:
Composer, conductor, and researcher Acre studied musical composition with Mariano Etkin and Gabriel Valverde and orchestral conducting with Guillermo Scarabino and Mario Benzecry at the Department of the Arts at La Plata National University in Buenos Aires, Argentina. In 2000, Acre founded the bachelor's degree in music at Universidad Loyola de Bolivia [Loyola University of Bolivia] in La Paz, where he served as the music department head and instructor. While at Loyola University, Acre spearheaded the development of a bachelor's of music degree in traditional orchestral instruments and established the PRETA Ensemble, which combines traditional Bolivian musical instruments with digital technologies, and the Loyola Sinfonietta. In addition, Acre has established various musical ensembles such as the Ensemble Contemporáneo TAKY, which exclusively plays contemporary Bolivian and Latin American classical music, and co-founded the Curucusí Ensemble with soprano Giovanna Montaño.
During his extensive career, Acre has taught at the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés [Major University of San Andrés], the Universidad Pública de El Alto [Public University of El Alto] (UPEA),  and the Universidad Autónoma Tomás Frías [Tomás Frías Autonomous University]. Between 2012 and 2016, he was the Orquesta Sinfonica Municipal[Municipal Symphony Orchestra] director at the Escuela Municipal de Artes de El Alto [Municipal School of Arts of El Alto] (EMDA). His more than 70 compositions are performed frequently inside and outside of Bolivia. In October 2016, he received the “Premio Nacional de Composición Orlando Alandia Pantoja” [Orlando Alandia Pantoja National Composition Award].  In 2017, the Venezuelan Symphony Orchestra premiered Gritos de Cóndor [Cries of a Condor], an honorable mention from the same contest from 2012. In 2017, Acre released his sell-out hit Los avatares de la Música Contemporánea en Bolivia [The Avatars of Contemporary Music in Bolivia], which examines the history of contemporary Bolivian music in the last decade and its leading figures. The book's success has prompted Acre to begin writing a second edition.
keywords: conductor; composer; author; researcher; educator; Universidad Loyola de Bolivia; Universidad Pública de El Alto; Ensemble Contemporáneo TAKY
creator: unknown

title: Gisela Rodriguez Fernandez
description:
Gisela Rodriguez Fernandez is an artist and educator from the Central Andes living and working between the ancient Inca empire and the unceded and occupied lands of the Chinook, Clackamas, Multnomah, and other Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest of the so-called United States. She has a PhD in Sociology from Portland State University and teaches various social sciences classes, including Latin American music, politics, and history. Dr. Rodriguez also taught for the BRAVO Youth Orchestras in Portland, Oregon, a program that improves the lives of underserved children through music. She has performed with many symphony orchestras across the United States and South America, including the Pensacola Symphony Orchestra in Pensacola, Florida, the Pan-American Symphony Orchestra, and the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia. 
Dr. Rodriguez uses music as a bridge to connect people and remove all the physical, mental, and spiritual borders around us. Unsurprisingly, her favorite music is fusion, which mixes forbidden alliances, such as electronic music, with traditional Andean melodies. Music is not just a cultural expression but a political praxis and resistance method deeply interconnected to the social context from which it emerges. Dr. Rodriguez’s music aims to capture its complexity.
keywords: violinist; artist; educator; sociologist; researcher; Portland State University; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Oregon, USA
creator: unknown

title: Gustavo Navarre
description:
A pioneer among the musicians of his generation, Navarre is one of the most influential Bolivian composers of his time. Born in La Paz in 1931, he began his formal musical education at an early age, and in 1947 he became a student of Egon-Carl Schif. The following year, he entered the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz to continue his piano studies under the tutelage of Alicia Eguino de Justiniano and Mario Estensoro. While at the conservatory, he studied music theory with Teófilo Molina and harmony and counterpoint with Erich Eisner. Nine years after entering the conservatory, he was appointed professor in 1957 and began to teach harmony, counterpoint, and composition as a professor at the conservatory. In 1968, he participated in a competition in Geneva, Switzerland, where he was awarded a scholarship to study music at the Ecole Normale de Musique in Paris, France. During this period, he studied orchestration, composition, and musical analysis with world-renowned composers such as Henri Dutilleux (1916-2013) and Marcel Mihalovici (1898-1985). After returning to Bolivia, Navarre became the Director of the COPLUMU in 1970. Navarre has received many recognitions, including several national awards, including the Ministry of Education Award and the prestigious Luz Mila Patiño Award. Navarre died in La Paz in 2006. 
Navarre was a prolific composer. Unfortunately, most of his work was lost in a fire in the 1990s. Items lost include original, plain copies, manuscripts, and a catalog of his works. His prolific production is known only through his colleagues, fellow musicians, family, and friends. Fellow composer Atiliano Auza describes his composition style as neo-romantic but with a local influence. Musicologists Suzanne Spicer Tiemstra and Gerard Béhague describe his style as combining neo-romanticism with Bolivian elements and nationalism. The musicologist Leslie Bethell affirms that Navarre had "created a neo-romantic language sometimes combined with features of Bolivian folk music.”
Navarre's work included written vocal works, sonatas, piano trios, string quartets, piano quintets, and larger orchestral compositions, including at least two symphonies. The news of this loss devastated the Navarre family and Bolivia's musical heritage. However, to the surprise of many, some of Navarre's compositions have emerged recently. Photocopies of a Sonata for violin and piano, a string quartet, a short Elegy for violin and piano, and a symphony in two movements have been found in private collections and the library of the National Symphony Orchestra in La Paz. In June 2012, during a concert trip to Bolivia, researcher Javier Pinell and co-researcher Sergio Ruiz became aware of these results and the idea of ​​compiling these manuscripts, their study, public presentation, and recording.
keywords: pianist; composer; educator; Luz Mila Patiño Award; Erich Eisner; Atiliano Auza Leon; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia
creator: unknown

title: Humberto Viscarra Monje
description: The Bolivian composer was born in Sorata in 1898 and died in La Paz in 1971. He studied at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz shortly after it opened under the direction of Peruvian David Molina. Later, he expanded his studies in Europe, specifically in Italy and France, where he became a piano virtuoso and a composer of international fame and level. He was also a notable writer, poet, and an illustrious educator. He directed the COPLUMU and was director and founder, with Armando Palmero, of the famous Academia Nacional de Música Man Césped [Man Césped Music Academy] in Cochabamba. His musical compositions are characterized by a combination of popular elements of his time and Bolivian native music. He introduced melodies with great expressive elegance and harmonic transparency in his piano works. Some of his noteworthy compositions include Pequeña Danza [Small Dance], Motivo Aymara [Aymara Reason], Capricho Andino [Andean Caprice], Allegretto Scherzando, and Rondino, his most popular piano piece.
keywords: pianist; composer; writer; poet; educator; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Academia Nacional de Música Man Césped; Cochabamba, Bolivia
creator: unknown

title: Isaac Terceros
description:
Terceros is the founder and artistic director of the Santa Cruz de la Sierra Philharmonic Orchestra in Bolivia. He is also currently serving as Interim Artistic Director of the Bloomington Symphony Orchestra in Indiana while completing his doctoral studies in orchestral conducting at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music under the mentorship of Maestros Arthur Fagen and Thomas Wilkins.
Mr. Terceros has conducted worldwide, including several cities in South America, the United States, Germany, France, Hungary, and Romania, among other European countries. He founded and conducted several ensembles in Bolivia, including the Santa Cruz Symphonic Band and the award-winning vocal ensemble Entrecantos. A passionate advocate for music education, he has taught at the Universidad Evangélica Boliviana [Bolivian Evangelical University] and served in various cultural leadership roles, including on the Arts Council of Santa Cruz, Bolivia. In 2017, he was awarded the Youth Peace Prize in the Arts by the Santa Cruz Youth Council, and in 2019, he received the Outstanding Young Person award from the Junior Chamber International (JCI TOYP) of Bolivia. 
His work with the Orquesta Filarmónica de Santa Cruz de la Sierra [Santa Cruz de la Sierra Philharmonic Orchestra], has received praise and recognition from audiences and press alike. Since its establishment in 2016, the Philharmonic has fast become an artistic pillar of the city and country, building solid relationships with civic institutions, businesses, and the public. Concerts have had a solid educational and historical impact on the city, as many programs include premieres from the symphonic canon, such as Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, Carl Orff's Carmina Burana, pieces from the Latin American symphonic repertoire, and various popular productions such as A Gospel Celebration, A Tribute to John Williams, and the musical Les Misérables. Mr. Terceros' adventurous projects have harnessed the storytelling power, rich diversity, and universal relevance of music to engage new audiences.
Mr. Terceros holds a master's degree in instrumental conducting from the University of Central Arkansas and a bachelor's in orchestral and choral conducting from the University of Sao Paulo in Brazil. Throughout his academic career, he has received numerous awards and grants for his research in music analysis, music technology, and choral conducting. He has published his findings in academic journals and conferences.
keywords: conductor; performer; educator; Youth Peace Prize; Indiana University Jacobs School of Music; University of Central Arkansas; Santa Cruz de la Sierra Philharmonic Orchestra; Santa Cruz, Bolivia; Indiana, USA
creator: unknown

title: Jorge Andres Ibáñez
description:
Ibáñez's music is characterized by its lyricism, clarity of form, refinement, spontaneity, and use of resonance and instrumentation. Born in La Paz, Bolivia, Ibáñez began his musical studies under the guidance of his parents, both distinguished Bolivian musicians. He graduated from the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz in 1983 and taught piano at the conservatory for three years after graduating. Ibáñez holds a Graduate Diploma in Piano from the Longy School of Music of Bard College in Cambridge, Massachusetts, a Bachelor of Music in Composition from the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston, Massachusetts, and a Master of Music in Composition from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. His primary teachers in composition have been Lukas Foss, Theodore Antoniou, Leonardo Balada, John McDonald, Malcolm Peyton, and Robert Kyr. He has also received piano lessons from Sally Pinkas, Gustavo Navarre Viscarra, and Alicia de Justiniano.
Ibáñez is a winner of several composition awards. He won second prize at the Simon Bolivar Composition Contest in 1983, the second prize Winner at the Humberto Viscarra Monje Piano Competition in 1985, an Honorable Mention at the Carnegie Mellon University Composition Contest in 1995, and won the third prize in the Teresa Rivera de Stahlie National Composition Contest in 1998. He frequently performs in concerts in South America and the United States as a member of Duo Ibáñez with his brother Luis Antonio Ibáñez, a violin and piano duo, and with Ritmos 3 [Rhythm 3], a violin, piano, and percussion trio. He also serves as the instrumentalist, composer, and member of the choral group Triad: Boston's Choral Collective. He recorded the album “In Memoriam” in 2014, a compilation that includes violin and piano compositions from Bolivian composers Antonio Ibáñez Rodriguez and Gustavo Navarre Viscarra and his works with Duo Ibáñez. In addition to his work as a composer, director, and musician, Ibáñez has taught music at the New World School for the Arts and Broward College in Miami, Florida. He currently teaches at Winchester Community Music School and Roxbury Community College. Ibáñez lives in Boston with his wife, Deborah, daughter Katarina, and son Mateo.
keywords: pianist; educator; Gustavo Navarre Viscarra; Simon Bolivar Composition Contest; Humberto Viscarra Monje Piano Competition; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; New England Conservatory of Music; Carnegie Mellon University; Duo Ibáñez; Massachusetts, USA
creator: unknown

title: Jose Maria Velasco Maidana
description: Velasco Maidana was born in Sucre in 1901. He composed several musical works for his ballet group and symphonic works. His work, Suite India, is an autochthonous reference of his work. In 1940, he founded the Symphony Concert Orchestra, the precursor to the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia. He also organized the Amerindian Ballet, with which he toured several countries in America and Europe. In addition to his musical career, Velasco Maidana is also known as the fundamental filmmaker of the silent stage of Bolivian cinema. His first major film was La Profecía del Lago [The Lake Prophecy] (1925), the story of the daughter of a landowner falling in love with an Aymara man that was never released due to government censorship. His second film of the time, Wara Wara (1930), a story of the Spanish conquest in the lake area, was positively received. Wara Wara was a grand feature film during this time, as it featured recreated set designs and models of the original period and a great cast. Velasco Maidana spent the last years of his life in the United States, where he died in 1989 in Texas at age 88.
keywords: filmmaker; composer; writer; ballet; Wara Wara (1930); National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Texas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Jose Miguel Pereira Muruchi
description:
Outstanding Bolivian cellist Miguel Pereira Muruchi has concertized as a soloist throughout his native country. He is currently a member of the Nightingale String Quartet at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR), where he is pursuing a Master of Music degree. At UNR, he is a graduate teaching assistant to Dr. Dmitri Atapine. Pereira Muruchi previously earned his Bachelor of Music degree from the University of Central Arkansas in Conway, Arkansas, in 2022 while studying with Dr. Stephen Feldman. Pereira Muruchi took the opportunity to study cello for one summer in Germany with Professor Wolfgang Nüsslein at the Musikakademie der Stadt Kassel [Academy of Music of The City of Kassel] after receiving a full scholarship to study at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in the city of La Paz. The Chamber of Deputies of the Plurinational State of Bolivia awarded Pereira Muruchi an “Honor for Cultural Merit” for his long artistic career and cultural contributions. Currently, Pereira Muruchi is the principal Cello of the UNR Orchestra and is also performing with the Reno Philharmonic Orchestra.
While living in Bolivia, Mr. Pereira was Principal of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia, as well as a member of the Orquesta Sinfónica Chuquiago Marka [Chuquiago Marka Symphony Orchestra], the Orquesta Filarmónica de Bolivia [Philharmonic Orchestra of Bolivia], Orquesta de Cámara La Paz [La Paz Chamber Orchestra], Orquesta de Cámara Tarija [Tarija Chamber Orchestra], Orquesta Sinfónica Juvenil de Bolivia [Youth Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia], and Los Andes Chamber Orchestra, the latter of which he also served as a conductor. An avid chamber musician, Pereira Muruchi has presented concerts with the Nuevo Mundo String Octet, Camerata del Sur, and he toured Europe with the Bolivian contemporary music ensemble TAKY Ensemble, performing concerts in Sweden, France, and Romania. Dedicated to teaching young cellists, he has taught at COPLUMU, Escuela Nacional de Música Luis Felipe Arce [Luis Felipe Acre National School of Music] in La Paz, and the Escuela Municipal de Bellas Artes [Municipal School of Fine Arts] in the city of El Alto.
keywords: cellist; performer; educator; conductor; Honor for Cultural Merit; TAKY Ensemble; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; University of Nevada; University of Central Arkansas; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Nevada, USA; Arkansas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Junior Tovar
description:
Tovar is a multifaceted musician, songwriter, and producer with extensive experience in various genres and stages of music production. He has recorded music as a musician and a sound engineer and has performed live in settings ranging from small recital halls to massive stadiums and arenas. Tovar's musical journey began when he started playing the piano at the young age of 6, followed by the violin at 9. He dedicated himself to the violin, which led him to study under Bolivia's top violin teacher, Maestro Jiri Sommer, from the Czech Republic. His hard work paid off as he auditioned and became part of numerous orchestras in Bolivia, such as the Orquesta Sinfónica Juvenil de Santa Cruz [Santa Cruz Youth Symphony Orchestra] and the Orquesta Filarmónica de Santa Cruz de la Sierra [Santa Cruz de la Sierra Philharmonic Orchestra], performing alongside renowned artists such as Carlos Buono, Elio Villafranca, and the Julliard Jazz Quartet.
Currently, Tovar is continuing his music instruction at the prestigious Brigham Young University–Idaho (BYU-Idaho) Rexburg, Idaho, where he received the "Talent Grant" award and is a student of Dr. Dallin Hansen. Besides the violin and piano, Tovar is also skilled in playing the mandolin and accordion, making him an incredibly versatile musician. Tovar's musical talent caught the attention of local artists in Bolivia, and he began performing popular music in 2014. He garnered millions of views through social media platforms by performing covers and gospel music. Today, Tovar is the lead vocalist for the Andean band Los Hermanos de los Andes [The Brothers of the Andes] (LHDLA) in the United States, with whom he has performed at several music festivals nationwide. He is also a frequent performer and speaker for the "Hi-Five Live" Facebook page, spreading messages of hope worldwide.
Throughout his career, Tovar has worked with various artists such as Emily Ray, Los Hermanos de Los Andes (LHDLA), Chris Syler (Latin Billboard Number 1), GENTRI, Adassa, Milton Cortez and Allie Gardner, among others. His talent has taken him to perform in numerous countries, including Bolivia, Peru, Argentina, Brazil, South Africa, Mozambique, and the United States. Tovar's musical talent has earned him many opportunities, including playing violin in the acclaimed movie Tu Me Manques [I Miss You], directed by Rodrigo Bellot and available on demand on HBOmax and Hulu. Overall, Tovar's remarkable skills as a musician, songwriter, and producer have taken him far, and he continues to inspire audiences worldwide with his talent and dedication to music.
keywords: cellist; performer; educator; conductor; Honor for Cultural Merit; TAKY Ensemble; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; University of Nevada; University of Central Arkansas; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Nevada, USA; Arkansas, USA
creator: unknown

title: Lluvia Bustos Soria
description:
Composer Bustos Soria received a bachelor's degree in music arts from the Bolivian Catholic University, a Master of Arts in musical composition, theory of cinema and film, television, and audiovisual media music from Beijing Film Academy (BFA), and a degree in electrical engineering from the Universidad Major San Andres [Higher University of San Andres] (UMSA) in La Paz. Bustos Soria has worked on commissions for the Orquesta Experimental de Instrumentos Nativos [Experimental Native Instruments Orchestra] (OEIN). This orchestra incorporates the sounds of traditional instruments from the Bolivian Andes to contemporary classical music. She has also worked with the Centro Cultural Simón I. Patiño [Cultural Center Simon I. Patiño] and the Festival PRO-ESCENA del Centro Cultural de España [PRO ESCENA Music Festival of the Cultural Center of Spain] (CCELP – AECID) in La Paz, Bolivia. In Beijing, Bustos Soria worked on the soundtrack of various short films selected to represent the Beijing Youth Studio at international film festivals. In January 2009, she worked on the soundtrack of Munian De Kunhuo [Complex and Baffling Old Age], produced in partnership with the Beijing Drama Academy and the Institute of Mental Health in Beijing. Bustos Soria also did the audio post-production of the documentary El Corral Y El Viento [The Corral and The Wind)] (2014) by Miguel Hilari. Her compositions have been played in different countries at contemporary music festivals and sound art festivals.
In addition to her work as a composer, Bustos Soria also heads different projects with the Museo Nacional de Etnografía y Folklore [National Museum of Ethnography and Folklore)] (MUSEF) archive, including cataloging, preserving, and recovery of film material and digitizing and editing analog cassettes from the Sound Documents Fund. She also heads a project that is working on adding audio descriptions and close captioning to Bolivian films, the project “El Color de la Imaginación” [The Color of Imagination] audio stories for children, volumes one and two. She has partnered with Sonido Con Alta Techonlogia (SCAT) [Sound with high technology], an audio and audiovisual production company, to develop the “Mapa sonoro del municipio de La Paz” [Sound map of the municipality of La Paz] project. Bustos Soria has also produced and organized the First Bolivian Tiflo-cinema Mini-festival, “Francesco Díaz Mariscal,” in 2014.
keywords: composer; electrical engineer; audio engineer; Bolivian Catholic University; Universidad Major San Andres; Beijing Film Academy; Sonido Con Alta Techonlogia (SCAT); Orquesta Experimental de Instrumentos Nativos; Beijing, China
creator: unknown

title: Luis Moya Salguero
description:
Moya is a composer of contemporary classical music. He has composed numerous works for piano, choir, symphony orchestra, chamber music, soloists, and orchestra. He has published three works for trio (piano, violin, and cello) in the series Compositores Bolivianos [Bolivian Composers], No. XXV, and Música para Trío [Music for Trio] (2004). In 2009, Moya authored the book Invenciones sobre la sonoridad Andina [Inventions on Andean Sonority], which is about the musical aesthetic thinking of Alberto Villapando. From 2011 to 2014, he was the president of the Asociación Boliviana de Autores, Investigadores, Compositores, Artistas y Músicos [Bolivian Association of Authors, Researchers, Composers, Artists, and Musicians] (ABAICAM), a non-profit association whose main objective is the promotion of creation, organization of training events, registration, development, dissemination and research of contemporary Bolivian music. Every year, ABAICAM organizes the Jornadas de Música Contemporánea [Contemporary Music Conferences] that take place in September.
In 2020, Moya published the book, Sin Privilegios, Horizonte de la formación Musical Superior en Cochabamba [Without Privileges, Horizons of Higher Musical Training in Cochamaba]. In 2013, Moya founded the bachelor's program in music at the Universidad Mayor de San Simón [Major University of San Simón] in Cochabamba. He headed the music department from 2016 to 2020. He is still an instructor at the Universidad Mayor de San Simón, teaching harmony, instrumentation, and orchestration.
keywords: author; composer; educator; researcher; Alberto Villapando; Major University of San Simón de Cochabamba; Asociación Boliviana de Autores, Investigadores, Compositores, Artistas y Músicos (ABAICAM); Jornadas de Música Contemporánea; Cochabamba, Bolivia
creator: MelinaPanozo

title: Martha Patricia Bedregal Velasco
description:
When Velasco was four years old, she started taking piano lessons. When she was nine, she began to study music at the  Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz. In 1990, at 18, Velasco decided to pursue a degree in architecture and, after graduation, worked in this field. Eight years later, in 1998, she returned to her music studies with her mentors, Maestro Javier Parrado and Maestra Mariana Alandia. In 2006, she began to pursue a bachelor’s degree in composition at the Universidad Loyola de Bolivia [Loyola University of Bolivia] in La Paz with Gastón Arce. Her return to music led Velasco to perform with the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia, Sociedad Coral Boliviana [Bolivian Choral Society], and the Orquesta Filarmónica de La Paz [Philharmonic Orchestra of La Paz] from 2001 to 2017. She also participated in projects such as the Trio ‘Abismos,’ a horn, piano, and cello ensemble as a pianist and composer, and the fusion project Mústika.
Between 1990 and 2013, Velasco taught at the COPLUMU, where she was appointed academic director. Velasco's composition premiered at the Jornadas de Música Contemporánea de Asociación Boliviana de Autores, Investigadores, Compositores, Artistas y Músicos [Bolivian Association of Authors, Researchers, Composers, Artists and Musicians] (ABAICAM) [Contemporary Music Journey] in Cochabamba in 2006. In 2014, she collaborated with the Stockholm Saxophone Quartet, a Swedish saxophone quartet dedicated to playing contemporary music, and commissioned a composition from her to add to their repertoire. The song she composed was performed in various concerts in North Europe and Africa. In 2020, the quartet requested a new composition for a children’s choir and saxophone quartet, Pachamama, which premiered in April 2021 in Sweden.
In addition to being a composer, Velasco is also a prolific music arranger. She arranged the artist and author of Sonia Rolón album “Voy Yo Misma a Desnudarte” [“I'm Going to Undress You Myself”] in 2011. She made orchestral arrangements for the Chilean Andean group Altiplano in 2012. She was the official arranger for the symphonic tribute projects for Pink Floyd (2013), Beatles (2014), and ABBA (2015) with Deuce Producciones. Velasco's trajectory as an arranger led her to work with the Colombian electronic experimental musical group Ambivalencias in 2014, with the Bolivian rock metal group Armadura and the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia. She also worked on the translation and arrangements for the Soda Stereo Unplugged along with the group Ruido Blanco in 2015. She arranged pieces for Sinfomore, a symphonic homage to Argentinian rock music. She also arranged for a string quartet for the Bolivian rock band Ciudad Líquida for the album “Frecuencias Fantasma” in 2016.
Velasco also made symphonic arrangements for the Festijazz, for maestro Gilberto Rojas's work in 2016, for the “Homenaje a la Mujer” [Homage to Women] in 2017, and arranged for and produced the concert “Sangre y Sueños” [Blood and Dreams] a tribute to Bolivian author and singer Marcelo Urioste. She also made symphonic arrangements for Manuel Monroy Chazarreta’s “Papirri Sinfónico” Concert in 2018 and symphonic arrangements for Adrian Barrenechea´s music for “Un Concierto Muy Sui Generis,” along with Nito Mestre in 2018. In 2020, she made an orchestral arrangement version of the song De Regreso Agradezco a la Vida [On the way back, I thank life] based on the cueca De Regreso [On the way back] from Bolivian composer Matilde Casazola and Gracias a la Vida [Thank to life] from Chilean composer Violeta Parra. These arrangements were performed virtually by the Orquesta Femenina de Bolivia [Bolivian Female Orchestra] and the Orquesta de Mujeres de Chile [Female Orchestra of Chile] on October 3rd of the same year. She is currently dedicating her time to teaching and composing.
keywords: pianist; composer; arranger; Gastón Arce; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Universidad Loyola de Bolivia; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Orquesta Femenina de Bolivia; Asociación Boliviana de Autores, Investigadores, Compositores, Artistas y Músicos (ABAICAM); Cochabamba, Bolivia
creator: unknown

title: Miguel Cerruto
description: At 20, Cerruto went to live in the United States and later Spain. When he was 31, he studied at the Conservatorio Superior de Música Manuel Castillo de Sevilla [Miguel Manuel Castilla Superior Conservatory of Music of Seville] in Seville, Spain, earning a teacher's diploma in classical guitar. As a student, he started composing pieces for guitar and other ensembles. He worked at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz from 1990 to 2000, where he created the Classical Guitar department along with Kazutoyo Ito and Gentaro Takada.
keywords: guitarist; composer; educator; Conservatorio Superior de Música Manuel Castillo de Sevilla; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; USA; Seville, Spain
creator: unknown

title: Naren Palomino Pardo
description:
A native of Cochabamba, Bolivia, Prado studied music at the Academia Nacional de Música Man Césped [Man Césped Music Academy] in Cochabamba, starting his piano studies with Prof. Betzabé Gutiérrez and Prof. Juan Carlos Toro. Upon graduating from the academy, he continued his studies in piano performance, choral and orchestral conducting, composition, and arranging under Prof. Koichi Fujii. After graduation, Prado joined the faculty of the music academy, where he taught piano and ear training. He was also the accompanist for the Children's Choir and Youth Choir and the conductor of the Man Césped Percussion Ensemble, Folk Orchestra, and Symphony Orchestra.
In 2018, Prado was accepted into the University of Central Arkansas (UCA) in Conway, Arkansas, where he studied under Dr. Neil Rutman. At UCA, he was the pianist for the UCA Wind Ensemble, UCA Percussion Ensemble, UCA Studio Jazz Ensemble, the Conway Symphony Orchestra, and other ensembles. Prado also placed honorable mention in the UCA Concerto/Aria Competition and won first place in the UCA Wind Ensemble Student Spotlight Competition, allowing him to perform George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" alongside the university's Wind Ensemble under the direction of Dr. Michael Hancock. Prado won the 2022 Matthay Association Competition, a festival held in Duluth, Minnesota, where he took master classes with Prof. John Perry and Prof. Aiko Onishi. In May 2022, he graduated with honors from UCA with a Bachelor in Music in Piano Performance. In August 2022, he started his studies for a Master of Music in Piano Performance at the University of Missouri-Kansas City Conservatory (UMKC) under the teaching of Prof. Sean Chen. At UMKC Conservatory, Prado was the rehearsal pianist for the opera at the conservatory. Now, he is a collaborative pianist for instrumentalists, the pianist for the UMKC Conservatory Symphony Orchestra, and a piano instructor at the UMKC Conservatory Academy. Recently, Prado was accepted into the UMKC Conservatory Collaborative Piano Program, where he will pursue a Master's in the Arts in Collaborative Piano with a graduate assistantship position.
keywords: pianist; performer; conductor; composer; arranger; educator; Matthay Association Competition; Academia Nacional de Música Man Césped; University of Central Arkansas; University of Missouri-Kansas City Conservatory; Conway Symphony Orchestra; Arkansas, USA

title: Nicolás Suarez Eyzaguirre
description:
Nicolas Suarez Eyzaguirre is a composer, pianist, arranger, consultant, and music producer. He received a Bachelor of Music from the Universidad Católica Boliviana San Pablo [Bolivian Catholic University San Pablo] (1978), a master’s (1986), and a Ph.D. in music (1997) from the Catholic University of America in Washington D.C. in the United States. Suarez Eyzaguirre was the composer in residence of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia from 2002 to 2005 and the Director of the  Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) from 2000 to 2005. He won the Primer Premio del Concurso de Composición “Adrián Patiño” [First Prize in the Composition Contest "Adrián Patiño] of the Municipal Mayor's Office of La Paz in 2010, 2014, and 2018. He conducted the National Symphony Orchestra at the "Wara Sinfónico" event in 2011 and, more recently, at the "Cantos de Amor" [Songs of Love] concert in November 2021.
In November 2011, Suarez Eyzaguirre presented his opera El Compadre [The Comrade], a work reprised in 2017. He has won the Premio Plurinacional de Composición Musical “Eduardo Abaroa” [Plurinational Prize for Musical Composition "Eduardo Abaroa"] twice in 2016 and 2017. Among his recordings that stand out are Canciones para niños [Songs for Children] Vol.1 (2009) and Vol.2 (2020), Música para orquesta, coro, canciones y ensambles [Music for orchestra, choir, songs, and ensembles] (2010) and Blues en las Rockas [Blues in the Rocks] (2013). In addition, Suarez Eyzaguirre also worked on producing and publishing his opera El Compadre (2019) in DVD format and the animated children’s title entitled Plantando sueños en el bosque [Planting Dreams in the Forest] (2020) available in DVD format. His composition work also extends into various musical genres. He has recorded with New Albion Records (1990), Pro Audio (2009 and 2011), Elektra (2013, 2019, 2020), León Estudios (2019), Discolandia (1994), OOdiscs, CT (1998), Kantus (2002).
keywords: pianist; composer; educator; arranger; consultant; producer; conductor; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Universidad Católica Boliviana de San Pablo; Catholic University of America; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Washington D.C., USA
creator: unknown

title: Oldrich Halas
description:
Composer, teacher, and graphic artist Halas was born in La Paz, Bolivia, in 1967 to a Potosi mother and a Czech father. In 1986, he debuted as a composer at a concert in La Paz, which he shared with Alberto Villalpando and Willy Pozadas. That same year, Halas entered the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz. However, shortly after, he traveled to the Federal Republic of Germany, where he continued his studies at the Pfälzische Musikakademie [Palatinate Music Academy] in the city of Speyer in the Rhineland Palatinate and then at the Hochschule für Musik Karlsruhe [University of Music Karlsruhe]. In 1996, he returned to Bolivia. Halas works include compositions for piano, vocal, solo instruments, chamber music, choral music, concert music, symphonic and incidental. His compositional work can be recognized according to the place and time it was generated. 
Halas’ juvenile work (1980 – 1986) includes an extensive collection of works, the vast majority outside the official catalog and the vast majority unpublished. Works from this time of production include the cantata El Canto de los Sepulcros [The Song for the Tombs] (1984) for soloists, mixed choir and chamber ensemble composed for the Sociedad Coral Boliviana [Bolivian Choral Society]; the Allegro Brusco Op.3 (1985); the Misa Interdicta [the Prohibited Mass] Op.6 (1987) and the melodrama for baritone and piano on the homonymous narrative by F. Kafka Report for an Academy Op.4 (1986). His European period (1987 – 1994) begins with the composition Concertino for transverse flute and string orchestra Op.8 (1988); Réquiem para la Selva Amazónica [Requiem for the Amazon Jungle] Op.10 (1990); wind quintet Op.12 (1992); and Toccata for solo cello Op.14 (1993).
Halas’ Bolivian period (1995 to the present) includes works that seek inspiration from Bolivian traditions and popular music. Representative works include Cantos Líticos [Lithic Songs] Op.16 for voice and piano; Álbum para un Ratón Criollo [Album for a Creole Mouse] Op.20 (1998), El Cóndor y la Tormenta [The Condor and the Storm] Op.24 (2001), Alasita - I Book Op. 28 (2004), Jacha Flowers Homenaje Blues [Jacha Flowers Homenaje Blues] Op.29 (2004), El Entierro del Pepino [The Cucumber Burial] Op.32 (2010), Waca Concertino Op.26 (2006 - 2018) and the burlesque for solo saxophone Chuta Cholero Op.41 (2020).
In addition to his solo work, Halas has also worked to create original soundtracks for films. He has worked for Oscar García on the soundtracks for movies by Jorge Sanjinés and Marcos Loayza. In 2005, he made the original music for the Fernando Vargas film “Di buen día a Papá” [Say good day to Dad]. As a music teacher, he has thrived as an academic authority in various positions. Between 2002 and 2003, he was a music professor at the Universidad Católica Boliviana San Pablo [Bolivian Catholic University San Pablo]. From 2002 to 20015, Halas served different roles in the COPLUMU; he was a member of the board of directors from 2002 to 2007, head of the Academic Unit from 2008 to 2010, executive director from 2010 to 2013, and rector from 2013 to 2015. Halas has been recognized and given several prizes as an artist and composer. In 2009, he received recognition for his 20 years of career disseminating music, artistic, and cultural events, granted by the Honorable Congress of the Republic of Bolivia. He also received recognition from the Parliamentary Brigade of the City of La Paz and the “Medalla al Mérito Cultural, Mención: Composición Musical” [Medal of Cultural Merit for Musical Composition] from the Asociación Boliviana “Pro Arte” [Bolivian Association "Pro Arte"] in 2014. Halas passed away in 2023.
keywords: educator; composer; graphic artist; Alberto Villalpando; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Pfälzische Musikakademie; Hochschule für Musik Karlsruhe; Universidad Católica Boliviana San Pablo; Sociedad Coral Boliviana; Germany
creator: Yanitai

title: Rachel Browne
description:
Browne was the principal harpist at the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia from 2004 to 2013. She is a part of the duo NorteSur with oboist and Andean music specialist Eduardo Cassapia. In Bolivia, Browne taught at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz and appeared in several folk, pop, and contemporary Bolivian music recordings. She holds a Medal of Cultural Merit awarded by the Plurinational State of Bolivia in 2013. Before her work in South America, she was a Whitinger Scholar at Ball State University in Muncie, Indiana.  Browne has also been awarded prizes at competitions by organizations such as the American Harp Society, the Glenn Miller Birthplace Society, and the National Alliance for Excellence. 
Notable performances for Browne include a solo appearance at the Osaka Women's University in Japan, a televised recital at the Los Angeles University Cathedral, and many appearances as a soloist with regional orchestras in the United States. Austin Opera and Central Texas Philharmonic frequently invite her as an orchestral harpist. As faculty at the Rocky Mountain Summer Harp Program in Steamboat, Colorado, Browne leads seminars on improvisation and arranging, music theory, and chamber music for harpists and regularly performs with NorteSur. She holds a Master of Music from the University of Texas at Austin.
keywords: harpist; performer; educator; Medal of Cultural Merit; Eduardo Cassapia; NorteSur; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Ball State University; University of Texas at Austin; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; La Paz, Bolivia; Texas, USA

title: Ramiro Soriano Acre
description:
Soriano Acre studied at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz, Bolivia. He studied under the Armenian Soviet composer Rubén Vartañán, who served as the Artistic Director and Principal Conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia in the 1970s. He studied under Boris Jaykin and Gennady Rozhdestvensky at the Tchaikovsky Conservatory in Moscow, where he obtained the title of Master of Arts, specializing in symphony orchestra and opera conducting and completed the "Aspirantura," a Postgraduate course.
From 1982 to 1991, Soriano Acre was the principal conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia and appeared to this day as a guest conductor. Since 1982, he has been director of Coral Nova in La Paz, Bolivia. In 1987, he was invited with a scholarship from the French government to observe the Orchestre de Paris [Paris Orchestra], the Orchestre National de France [French National Orchestra], and the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France [Radio France Philharmonic Orchestra] for four months. 
Soriano Acre has conducted in the United States, Russia, Portugal, Argentina, Peru, Colombia, and Ecuador. He founded the National Symphony Orchestra of Honduras in 1990 and was its Principal Conductor until 1994. As a composer, he has composed for orchestra, choir, chamber, vocal, and solo instruments; he has also done choral arrangements and musical compositions for film.
keywords: conductor; composer; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Tchaikovsky Conservatory; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; National Symphony Orchestra of Honduras; Moscow, Russia; Honduras
creator: Sromerobolivia

title: Ronaldo Christian Peña Guillén
description:
Peña Guillen began his musical studies at the age of ten. At sixteen, he started his studies at the Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica [Plurinational Conservatory of Music] (COPLUMU) in La Paz 1991. In 1999, he graduated from the conservatory with distinction as a classical guitarist. In 2013, Peña Guillen began to study music at the Universidad Loyola de Bolivia [Loyola University of Bolivia] in La Paz. He also holds a bachelor’s degree in pedagogy from the Universidad Autónoma del Beni [Autonomous University of Beni] in Trinidad, Bolivia. 
In addition to his academic studies, Peña Guillen has also studied guitar under Miguel Cerruto and Gentaro Takada and participated in master classes with renowned guitarists Piraí Vaca, Javier Calderón, Ben Kearsley, Christopher Jaggins, and Gerardo Pérez. He attended seminars on Chopin’s and Bach’s work with Spanish pianist Inocencio Negrín. While at the conservatory, he studied composition with Gastón Arce and attended seminars with composers Cergio Prudencio, Edgar Alandia, José Luis Prudencio, and Graciela Paraskevaidis. While studying at the conservatory, Peña Guillen began to teach classical guitar, solfeggio, music theory, harmony, counterpoint, and musical forms in 1996. He enjoys helping to train many generations of musicians, introducing new methodologies, and incorporating innovative resources in musical pedagogy. He is currently a teacher at the COPLUMU, where he teaches harmony, counterpoint, musical forms, and analysis. He has also taught at the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés [Major University of San Andrés] (UMSA) in La Paz.
Peña Guillen is also a prolific orator. He periodically lectures at seminars and conferences on Christian Worldview from 2008 to date and other courses on different musical themes. Of Peña Guillen’s compositions for guitar and orchestra, two stand out from his body of works. The first is the piece Concerto No. 1, the first Bolivian work of its kind, premiered in 2007 by the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia with Héctor Osaky on guitar. The second is the Fire Concert (Concert No. 2, 2014), which premiered in 2016 by guitarist Marcos Puña. His body of work also includes several piano pieces, including two compositions that were awarded a first and second prize for composition in the Concurso Nacional de Obras Pianísticas para niños “María Teresa Rivera-Sthalie” [National Competition of Piano Works for children, “María Teresa Rivera-Sthalie”] with his works Juegos y Acuarelas [Games and Watercolors], in 2012. Peña Guillen has also composed many works for solo guitar, chamber music, compositions for symphonic bands, wind instruments, and synthesizers. In 2015, he composed the work for solo guitar Auqui-Auqui [Here-Here] for the renowned Japanese classical guitarist Kazhuito Yamashita.
keywords: guitarist; composer; educator; orator; Concurso Nacional de Obras Pianísticas para niños “María Teresa Rivera-Sthalie”; Miguel Cerruto; Gastón Arce; Cergio Prudencio; Conservatorio Plurinacional De Musica en Bolivia; Universidad Loyola de Bolivia; Universidad Mayor de San Andrés; National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia; Trinidad, Bolivia
creator: Juan Pablo Miranda Alberto

title: Simeón Tadeo Roncal Gallardo
description:
Born in Sucre, Roncal Gallardo was the son of Mrs. Rosa Gallardo and Juan Roncal. His father was the maestro of the Catedral Metropolitana de La Plata [Chapel of the Metropolitan Cathedral of La Plata], organist, and cantor of the Iglesia Matriz de Potosí [Mother Church of Potosí]. He began to study piano at the age of seven with his father. After surpassing his father’s knowledge, he received lessons from the Spanish instructor Emilio Gott. At nine, he became the organist of the Catedral Metropolitana de Sucre [Metropolitan Cathedral of Sucre]. Roncal Gallardo studied and taught himself harmony, structure, and musical composition. At 13, he was appointed the second organist of the metropolitan cathedral. He was known as a piano virtuoso and very affectionately called the left-hander for his ability to play the bass notes on the piano.
As a composer, Roncal Gallardo produced 40 cuecas for concerts, kaluyos, dances, marches, and hymns. He wrote and dedicated the cueca Huérfana Virginia [Orphan Virginia] to his wife, Mrs Virginia Cortés, after her mother's death. He was one of the founders of the Sociedad Filarmónica de Sucre [Philharmonic Society of the city of Sucre] and one of the principal components of Gesta Barbara in Potosi. He worked as a piano teacher in schools in Potosí, Bolivia, where he lived for ten years from 1917 to 1927 and joined Gesta Bárbara. In 1927, he moved to La Paz, where he lived until his death on January 13, 1953.
keywords: pianist; composer; organist; educator; Catedral Metropolitana de Sucre; Sociedad Filarmónica de Sucre; Potosí, Bolivia; La Paz, Bolivia
creator: unknown
source: Instituto de Formación Artística Simeón Roncal Facebook

title: Teofilo Vargas Candia
description:
Vargas Candia was born in Quillacollo on November 3, 1866, and died in Cochabamba on February 3, 1961. Vargas Candia was a Bolivian violinist, vocalist, composer, and director. In 1893, he became the choir director at the Catedral Metropolitana de San Sebastián  [Metropolitan Cathedral of Saint Sebastian] in Cochabamba. He founded the music school (1884) and the conservatory (1907) in Cochabamba. Vargas Candia was the conservatory's director from 1907 to 1956, and in 1957, it was renamed the Conservatorio de Música Teófilo Vargas [Teófilo Vargas Candia Conservatory] in honor of his service.
Vargas Candia’s compositions Aires Nacionales de Bolivia [National Airs of Bolivia] in six volumes, Himno de Cochabamba [the Hymn of Cochabamba], Quillacollo, the melodramas Aroma and Coronilla, and his Christmas Oratory illustrate popular Bolivian forms. At 16, he composed his first composition for piano and violin, which would later be part of the first volume of his works Aires Nacionales de Bolivia [National Airs of Bolivia]. Its second volume was printed in 1940 with 22 cuecas and dances for voice and piano. The following year, the third volume and part of Vargas Candia’s work Aires Nacionales de Bolivia [National Airs of Bolivia] was printed in Bolivia and Santiago, Chile; this volume includes 22 pieces for voice, overtures, preludes, dances, symphonic poems, songs, and patriotic marches. His fourth volume was edited and printed in Argentina, containing Christmas carols, songs, hymns, and funeral marches.
keywords: violinist; composer; vocalist; conductor; director; Catedral Metropolitana de San Sebastián en Cochabamba; Conservatorio de Música Teófilo Vargas; Cochabamba, Bolivia
creator: unknown
source: AHORA Historias y Leyendas de Bolivia- Facebook

title: Vanesa Young
description: Young has been studying music since 1995 and specializing in clarinet at the Plurinational Conservatory of Music in La Paz, Bolivia. In 2005, she moved to Hawaii to improve her English and later to then apply for a bachelor’s degree in music from Brigham Young University (BYU)-Hawaii in Laie, Hawaii for about two years and then transferred to BYU in Provo, Utah to attend the extensive and competitive music program there. She graduated with a bachelor’s in music from BYU in 2012. Young has performed in different ensembles as well as some solos. Besides music, she also studied accounting and languages, she speaks Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, English and some Hebrew. Young has also worked as a genealogy researcher for Italian and Latin American families.
keywords: clarinetist; performer; accountant; genealogy researcher; Brigham Young University-Hawaii; Brigham Young University; Plurinational Conservatory of Music; Hawaii, USA; Utah, USA
creator: unknown
